meta.description:
Label Generation Rules for Swedish

Overview

This document specifies a reference set of Label Generation Rules for Swedish using a limited repertoire as appropriate for a second level domain.

Repertoire

references converge on 42 (29+13) Latin code points, with an additional 9 extensions. The repertoire here adds U+00E6 LATIN SMALL LETTER AE and U+00F8 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH STROKE, both of which are used in neighboring Denmark and Norway.

In addition, reference [605] cites use of these letters in foreign names:

  • U+00EB LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH DIAERESIS

  • U+00ED LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH ACUTE

  • U+00F1 LATIN SMALL LETTER N WITH TILDE

  • U+00F5 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH TILDE

They have been added to the core repertoire.

The Latin repertoire of the IDN table published in the IANA Repository of IDN Practices for the .se ccTLD includes code points for Swedish plus all the official Latin-based minority languages, such as Finnish [700]. This goes beyond the scope of a language-based LGR.

Excluded code points

Letters documented in some references but not included:

  • U+00E3 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH TILDE

  • U+00EA LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00EC LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH GRAVE

  • U+00EE LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00F0 LATIN SMALL LETTER ETH

  • U+00F2 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH GRAVE

  • U+00F4 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00F9 LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH GRAVE

  • U+00FA LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH ACUTE

  • U+00FB LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00FD LATIN SMALL LETTER Y WITH ACUTE

  • U+00FE LATIN SMALL LETTER THORN

  • U+00FF LATIN SMALL LETTER Y WITH DIAERESIS

  • U+0101 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH MACRON

  • U+0107 LATIN SMALL LETTER C WITH ACUTE

  • U+011B LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH CARON

  • U+012B LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH MACRON

  • U+0142 LATIN SMALL LETTER L WITH STROKE

  • U+0159 LATIN SMALL LETTER R WITH CARON

  • U+015B LATIN SMALL LETTER S WITH ACUTE

  • U+0161 LATIN SMALL LETTER S WITH CARON

  • U+0163 LATIN SMALL LETTER T WITH CEDILLA

  • U+017A LATIN SMALL LETTER Z WITH ACUTE

  • U+01CE LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH CARON

  • U+01D0 LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH CARON

  • U+01D2 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH CARON

  • U+01D4 LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH CARON

  • U+01E5 LATIN SMALL LETTER G WITH STROKE

  • U+01E7 LATIN SMALL LETTER G WITH CARON

  • U+01E9 LATIN SMALL LETTER K WITH CARON

  • U+01EF LATIN SMALL LETTER EZH WITH CARON

  • U+0213 LATIN SMALL LETTER R WITH INVERTED BREVE

  • U+0259 LATIN SMALL LETTER SCHWA

  • U+0292 LATIN SMALL LETTER EZH

Extended code points

A number of letters not considered essential to writing the core vocabulary of the language are nevertheless in common use. Where they have not been added to the core repertoire, they are flagged as "extended-cp" in the table of code points. A context is provided that by default will prohibit labels with such extended code points. To support extended single code points or code point sequences, delete the context "extended-cp" from their repertoire definition.

Reference [702] cites these extensions for the major Sami orthographies.

  • U+00E2 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00EF LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH DIAERESIS

  • U+010D LATIN SMALL LETTER C WITH CARON

  • U+0111 LATIN SMALL LETTER D WITH STROKE

  • U+0144 LATIN SMALL LETTER N WITH ACUTE

  • U+014B LATIN SMALL LETTER ENG

  • U+0167 LATIN SMALL LETTER T WITH STROKE

  • U+017E LATIN SMALL LETTER Z WITH CARON

These have been included here in the extended repertoire.

Variants

None.

Character Classes

This LGR defines no named character classes.

Rules

Common rules only:

  • Hyphen Restrictions — restrictions on the allowable placement of hyphens (no leading/ending hyphen and no hyphen in positions 3 and 4). These restrictions are described in section 4.2.3.1 of RFC5891 [120]. They are implemented here as context rule on U+002D (-) HYPHEN-MINUS.

  • Leading Combining Marks — restrictions on the allowable placement of combining marks (no leading combining mark). This rule is described in section 4.2.3.2 of RFC5891 [120].

Actions

Actions included are the default actions for LGRs as well as those needed to invalidate labels with misplaced combining marks.

Methodology and Contributors

This reference LGR for Swedish for the 2nd Level has been developed by Michel Suignard and Asmus Freytag, verified in expert reviews by Michael Everson, Nicholas Ostler, and Wil Tan, and based on multiple open public consultations.

References

General references for the language:

  • Svenska språknämnden. 1991. Svenska skrivregler. Stockholm: Almqvist & Wiksell. ISBN 91-21-11280-0

  • Tekniska nomenklaturcentralen, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

  • Wikipedia: "Swedish orthography", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swedish_alphabet

  • Omniglot: "Swedish (svenska)" htm http://www.omniglot.com/writing/swedish.htm

In the listing of the repertoire by code point, references starting from [0] refer to the version of the Unicode Standard in which the corresponding code point was initially encoded. Other references (starting from [100]) document usage of code points. For more details, see the Table of References below.

reference.comment: Code points cited were originally encoded in Unicode Version 1.1

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium. The Unicode Standard, Version 6.3.0, (Mountain View, CA: The Unicode Consortium, 2013. ISBN 978-1-936213-08-5) http://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode6.3.0/
Internetstiftelsen i Sverige (IIS), "IDN Reference table for Swedish language" https://github.com/dotse/IDN-ref-tables/blob/master/language-tables/swedish-lang-ref-table.txt
Repository of IDN practices at IANA: Stiftelsen för Internetinfrastruktur, TLD:.se for language sv-SE. https://www.iana.org/domains/idn-tables/tables/se_sv-se_1.0.html
RFC5891, Internationalized Domain Names in Applications (IDNA): Protocol http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5891

reference.comment: This table lists only the characters outside the set a-z

references.reference: ISO/IEC 6937 Third Ed. 2001-12-17- Information technology — Coded graphic character set for text communication — Latin alphabet: Table D.1 (p 35) Use of Latin alphabetic characters.

reference.comment: Code points cited form the standard set

reference.comment: Code points cited are from an extended set

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the Auxiliary set

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 1: Letters essential for the language

references.reference: Tekniska nomenklaturcentralen, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 2: Letters commonly used, but not essential

references.reference: Tekniska nomenklaturcentralen, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: Code points cited are supported in a national edition of ISO-646.

reference.comment: The table only lists code points beyond A-Z

reference.comment: This table covers not only Swedish, but all official minority languages in Sweden

rule.name: leading-combining-mark
rule.comment: RFC5891 restrictions on placement of combining marks

rule.name: hyphen-minus-disallowed
rule.comment: RFC5891 restrictions on placement of U+002D
no consecutive hyphens in third and fourth

rule.name: extended-cp
rule.comment: code points from the extended range

action.comment: by default, labels with leading combining marks are invalid
